definition:
A complex function $f\!: D \to \mathbb{C}$, where $D$ is a domain of the
complex plane, having the derivative $$\frac{df}{d \overline{z}}$$ in
each point $z$ of $D$, is said to be [*antiholomorphic*]{} in $D$.\
The following conditions are :

-   $f(z)$ is antiholomorphic in $D$.

-   $\overline{f(z)}$ is holomorphic in $D$.

-   $f(\overline{z})$ is holomorphic in
    $\overline{D} \,:=\, \{\overline{z}\;\vdots\;\, z \in D\}$.

-   $f(z)$ may be to a power series
    $\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n(\overline{z}-u)^n$ at each $u \in D$.

-   The real part $u(x,\,y)$ and the imaginary part $v(x,\,y)$ of the
    function $f$ satisfy the equations $$\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} 
    \;=\; -\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}, \qquad 
      \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \;=\; \frac{\partial v}{\partial x}.$$
    N.B. the of minus; cf. the .\

**Example.** The function
$\displaystyle z \mapsto \frac{1}{\overline{z}}$ is antiholomorphic in
$\mathbb{C}\!\smallsetminus\!\{0\}$. One has
$$f(z) \;=\; \frac{z}{|z|^2} 
       \;=\; \underbrace{\frac{x}{x^2\!+\!y^2}}_{u}+i\underbrace{\frac{y}{x^2\!+\!y^2}}_{v}$$
and thus $$\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} 
\;=\; \frac{y^2\!-\!x^2}{(x^2\!+\!y^2)^2},  \qquad
\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}
\;=\; \frac{x^2\!-\!y^2}{(x^2\!+\!y^2)^2},  \qquad 
\frac{\partial u}{\partial y} 
\;=\; -\frac{2xy}{(x^2\!+\!y^2)^2},  \qquad
\frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \;=\; -\frac{2xy}{(x^2\!+\!y^2)^2}.$$
